title: tims-tales-wise-old-witch
story: HAPPY St Andrewrsquos Day! The results of a poll on peoplersquos favourite Scots word by Scottish Book Trust was revealed this week.So herersquos a tale that includes all the top  favourite Scots words identied in the poll, plus some mair:THE weather matched the young wersquos mood: dreich.By the time she reached the witchrsquos cottage at the foothills of the Lammermuirs, she was soaked.ldquoOch, come in hen, ye look drookit, said the old woman sympathetically. They sat by the fire together.ldquoNoo how can I help ye  asked the old woman.The young we sighed.ldquoI just cannae thole it onymair, she said, getting upset.The old woman listened, waiting for the young woman to compose herself.ldquoItrsquos ma mither-in-law, she bides wi us and, weel, shersquos makin ma le a misery.ldquoHow sae  asked the old woman.ldquoI can dae naethin richt accordin tae her ma cookin is awfu, my hoose is mingin, I canne gie an opinion aboot onythin withoot her sayin the opposite, she treats me asIrsquom glaikit. Irsquom totally scunnerd wi it.ldquoI see, said the witch, ldquoand how can I help ye wi this ldquoI want her oot ma le, I want her deid.ldquoDeid  The witch seemed genuinely shocked.ldquoAye, deid, gone, awa. I just want her oot ma hoose and oot ma le.ldquoWeel, she doenae hae tae be deid fir that, suggested the witch.ldquoAye she does, I dinnae want her aroond. Shersquoll come knocking oan the door. Please can ye help me. I want her deid... er, wi oot it, ye ken, weel sae it isnae murder.ldquoBut it wud be murder ma dear.The young woman bent her head low and began to whisper assomeone might overhear their conversation.ldquoI ken, but ye are a witch, abody says ye hae potions fir onything. Please, I have siller. Mak it look natural. Then me an ma husband can get oan wi oor lives thegither.The witch thought for a moment, then nodded her head.ldquoVery weel, I will help ye, but ye maun dae whit I say.The we smiled with relief: ldquoThank ye.The old woman went ben the hoose to where she kept her herbs and ingredients. The young woman was curious and tried to sneak a look but the witch told her to stay by the fireside until she was finished.Then she came through holding a small bottle of potion.ldquoHere, she said to the we. ldquoThis will dae the trick. Ye maun put ane sma drap o this potion in yer mither-in-lawrsquos tea every day.ldquoBut she maks her ain tea, said the young woman, ldquoshe ay complains I cannae mak tea the proper way.ldquoWeel, ye maun find a way fir her tae allow ye tae mak her tea, said the witch. ldquoThen every day sit wi her as she drinks the tea. She maun drink it a.The we smiled: ldquoHow lang will it tak ldquoOch, mebbes twa months, ye maun use up the hale bottle. Then it will tak effect a few days ater the last drap has been drunk.ldquoTwa months!ldquoAye hen, it must be gradual, otherwise folk will suspect.The young woman clutched the bottle and nodded.ldquoNoo can I hae the siller, asked the witch, and the we willingly paid.ldquoMind tae gie the bottle a wee shoogle afore ye yaise it, the witch advised, ldquoand hud yer wheesht aboot this, or wersquoll baith hang.ldquoO course, said the young woman as she left the witchrsquos house.The weather had lted, as had her mood. Soon her problems would be over, she thought to herself.The witch watched her go, then closed the door. She had a knowing grin on her face.Two months later there was a desperate knocking on the old womanrsquos door. She looked out of the window and saw the young we standing just outwith the cottage, in a terrible state.So she opened her door.ldquoPlease, please help me, begged the young woman.The witch took her inside. The young woman had run all the way and her shawl had become wrapped round her hair, and her dress was dishevelled with the wind.ldquoOch hen, ye are in a richt fankle, sort yersel oot and sit by the fire fir a warm.The young we rearranged her clothes and started to greet as she spoke.ldquoHae ye got an antidote fir the potion please say ye huv, she said.ldquoAn antidote, hen ldquoAye, Irsquove changed ma mind. I gied ma mither-in-law a cup of tea wi the last drap o potion. I watched her drink and then she telt me that I mak a braw cup of tea and that she wis glad her son hud marrit me! It wis in that moment I realised I didnae want her deid!ldquoI see, said the witch. ldquoIrsquom afraid there is nae antidote fir the potion.The young women cradled her head in her hands. ldquoWhit huv I done, what huv I done, she cried to herself.ldquoYe huv got tae ken her, thatrsquos whit yersquove done, said the witch. ldquoAs ye spent time wi her making sure she drank her tea, ye will have talked, am I richt ldquoAye, sobbed the we, ldquoand she listened tae. I ken shersquos an auld witch sometime, er nae offence, but I understand her better noo.The witch smiled. ldquoGuid, she said, ldquonoo ye can gang hame and keep oan huvin the tea thegither, without the potion.ldquoBut shersquos goanie be deid in a few days, sobbed the we.ldquoNaw she isnae, replied the witch, ldquothe potion wis just a few herbs that wouldnae hairm even a wee beastie.ldquoWhat  Ye telt me that it would kill her! protested the we.ldquoNo I didnae, I said it would work ater twa months. And it has. It wis the hatred ye hud that needed kilt, no yer mither-in-law. And the same goes fir her.The young we was so relieved. For a moment she wondered about asking for her money back, but she realised the potion had indeed done its job.Her relationship with her mother-in-law was not always easy, but they had regular cups of tea and chats together, and often they would laugh as they shared memories and stories from le.ldquoThe claes are in a richt bumfle, said the mother-in-law the following day, then she smiled. ldquoBut letrsquos hae oor tea first and we can sort the claes thegither.The we thought to herself that the witch was indeed a wise woman.

title: community-kitchen-looks-raise-3-000-festive-raffle

title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-win-3-000-boost-good-cause
story: The pupils won their schoolrsquos Young Philanthropist Initiativecompetition, which saw them researching a social issue and delivering a presentation on it, with the best presentation receiving a pound, grant.The four pupils ndash Mairi Johnston, Jamila Sode-Woodhead, Kristina Grant and Emilee Large ndash donated their prize money to Muirfield Riding Therapy, where two of the group volunteer at a Friday childrenrsquos session.Their presentation was about the West Fenton-based charity, which offers horse riding therapy to children and adults with ious disabilities.Kristina said: ldquoThe highlight of the YPI course was the final round ndash winning the prize money for our charity made me feel very accomplished and as though I could make a real dference for the community and those who use the charity.ldquoI think schools should educate students more on disabilities and how they can help those who have them in everyday le. To have a group of our own pupils campaign successfully within the school and to win important funding for them is a real credit to themselves and the school!ldquoA big well done to all the effort that has gone into this yearrsquos project across S and thanks to our  of judges: depute headteacher Robert Jones, our head boy and head girl, and Roy Symon from North Berwick Rotary Club.Susan Law, service co-ordinator at Muirfield Riding Therapy and coach at the session the girls volunteer at, said: ldquoItrsquos brilliant. title: new-learning-hub-now-open-scottish-seabird-centre
story: The team have been working in partnership with Glasgow Science Centre for  months to transform all aspects of the five-star visitor experience and educational resources at the centre, which will reopen completely on Saturday  December followed by a formal launch in January.The learning hub will provide a more engaging and flexible space for inspiring and educating visiting schools, youth and further education groups.The new look learning hub and marine workshops are now available to book and it continues to be used by the charityrsquos weekly wildle watch groups, which are supported by the Scottish Wildle Trust.All of the furniture from the old education classroom has been given to Zero Waste Dunbar, a non-profit social enterprise which aims to keep good things in local circulation, rather than sending them to landfill.Launching the new hub, with young people from the centrersquos Wildle Watch Group, Provost, John McMillan said ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre has been a key part of East Lothianrsquos tourism and education offering for nearly  years. The new learning hub offers a high quality and flexible space that can be used by both East Lothian schools and residents, and those from further afield.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre, added: ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment is exceptional and erse. There is a growing awareness of both its importance and the pressures it is under ndash not least from the climate crisis, invasive non-native species, underwater noise and marine pollution. title: bay-city-rollers-star-saves-dog-stuck-hole-two-days
story: Bay City Rollers guitarist Stuart lsquoWoodyrsquo Wood was to prove the hero after Kruger, a -year-old black Labrador, went missing on Sunday, November , at about pm.Kruger was on his regular evening walk with owner Janette Murray, , of North Berwickrsquos Rhodes Park, next to the former East Lothian Council depot at Lime Grove.But after going to investigate a scent, he did notwhen called.Janettersquos daughter, -year-old Donna Denton, of the townrsquos Couper Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoHe is a rehomed dog, my mum got him when he was three.ldquoHe is quite timid but very, very friendly and doesnrsquot growl or bark at people ndash I have two kids and hersquos great with them.ldquoIf he does wander off he comes back as soon as he canrsquot see you, he always stays very close.ldquoWe now know the reason he didnrsquot come back this time. The lady from search and rescue said dogs donrsquot bark for help, only when they feel threatened.Kruger was found two days later by Bay City Rollers star Wood at about .am on Tuesday ndash the musician, who was on holiday in North Berwick, was one of  looking for the missing dog.He later posted on Facebook to say ldquothanks for the lovely messages and praising everyone who ldquosearched relentlessly.ldquoWell done everyone ndash we got lucky! he added.The terried dog was eventually found just metres from where he went missing.People all over North Berwick had helped in the search, not realising that Kruger was so close by.One man checked every bunker on the  holes at nearby Glen Golf Club ndashcounting  in total.Kruger gained access to the derelict Lime Grove site through a broken fence.Donna, a childminder and registered nurse, said: ldquoThe hole he fell down was no bigger than  centimetres by  centimetres, he couldnrsquot even lie down in it and was sitting up the whole time he was down there. We couldnrsquot even get our feet in there to help lt him out.ldquoWe phoned the fire brigade as we didnrsquot know what to do but my husband ended up putting a hoist around him and, with another manrsquos help, lting Kruger out with brute force.And she added: ldquoThe area he was found in is such a state and an absolute junkyard ndash therersquos broken bins and slabs everywhere, graffiti etc. It is not safe and is not secure.During the search, Donna contacted the police, SSPCA, search and rescue, the council and Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home, though she said she ldquocouldnrsquot get through to the dog warden at the council.After being rescued and wrapped up in blankets, Kruger was then sent to the vets for a check-up.Donna added: ldquoA man from the council had keys to the gate at the site and let me reverse my car in so I could put Kruger in the back.ldquo[Kruger] was really stf, so we had to carry him into the car and into the vets.ldquoHe was put on some fluids but my mum was able to get him home later that night luckily he wasnrsquot hurt.An appeal to find Kruger posted on social media attracted plenty of attention, something Donna was not expecting.She was full of praise for everyone who helped out, saying: ldquoEveryone was amazing. I had people I didnrsquot know come up to me at the school gates saying they were going to look for Kruger. We were just so lucky it was two mild nights when he was down there.ldquoMy mum will be  next year but was out all day trying to look for him, she didnrsquot want to stop or turn back. She was determined to find him.Since the incident, the hole has been covered with a slab, but the fence still remains damaged.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIf anyone is aware of an uncovered manhole then itrsquos recommended that they report the exact location to the council, who will investigate further to make it safe.ldquoThis can be done online or via our out of hours number:  .

title: world-champ-josh-taylor-enjoys-special-day-hibs
story: The county star, who paraded his world title belts on the pitch at half-time, said: ldquoWhat a great reception at Easter Road. I canrsquot wait to have a fight here one day.The Tartan Tornado also sat down with Hibs TV and discussed sneaking into games as a child and his dream of fighting under the stadium lights in future.A club spokesperson said: ldquoWe are all proud of Joshrsquos achievements and we know therersquos plenty more to come. title: new-musselburgh-bar-gets-go-ahead
story: The Musselburgh Bar and Kitchen, formerly the Mexican restaurant Habaneros on High Street, was granted a iation of premises licence by East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board last week.Owner Star Pubs  Bars had applied for: extension of opening hours from midnight to am on a Thursday use of premises for clubs and group meetings an outdoor drinking area changes both internally to the building to re-position bar and seating areas and extension of the rear drinking smoking area outside.A number of objections centred around concerns of possible noise disturbance and smoke from the outdoor area.The board heard that the outdoor smoking area would be moved from its present location away from neighbouring properties and that this area would also be covered by CCTV.Members of the licensing board agreed to grant permission with conditions. They included that children and young people under  could only be on the premises after pmthey were having a meal or attending a private, pre-arranged , and that CCTV was operational both within and outside the building.In addition, the beer garden would close at pm and an entertainment licence was not granted so no recorded or live music could be played outside.The new bar had previously received planning permission.A spokesperson for Star Pubs  Bars said the premises would be turned into ldquoa modern premium bar.She said it was hoped that a new licensee would take on the venture, which would offer food throughout the day and alfresco dining.She said the proposed investment followed another recent refurbishment project involving Star Pubs  Bars at The Seaglass Inn, Port Seton, previously the Wemyss Hotel.

title: general-election-candidates-lock-horns-hustings
story: The event ndash at St Andrew Blackadder Church ndash saw the candidates answering questions submitted by the public ahead of the election next Thursday.Organised by North Berwick and District Association of Churches, it was chaired by Keith Stewart QC.Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield began by saying that serving as MP for the last two years had been a pleasure and a privilege.He also said: ldquoI am the only pro-Union person sitting on this  that can win here, which Conservative candidate Craig Hoy was quick to disagree with.David Sisson, UKIP, used a cookie jar analogy to make his partyrsquos position on Brexit clear saying: ldquoThe cookies belong to us. Itrsquos time we get them back and we can work out how we split them up once we have them back.Answering a question on how to tackle climate change Robert OrsquoRiordan, Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoI think that one of the best ways is to stay within the EU.The SNPrsquos candidate Kenny MacAskill said the country needed to disinvest in fossil fuels.The next question asked candidatesthey thought there ought to be a  per cent majority threshold on referendums.Mr MacAskill said he didnrsquot, adding: ldquoPeople werenrsquot voting for a no deal Brexit, that was never put forward. I agree that the majority prevails, but I think we have to realise thatyou win by one the winner canrsquot have all.Mr Hoy said he would agree there should be a threshold in future elections.He added: ldquoI understand why Kenny doesnrsquot support it because the SNP can barely secure  per cent, never mind  per cent, for independence.Candidates were then asked why they should be trusted by the public.Mr Sisson took this opportunity to point out that he wasnrsquot a politician and he was standing because he felt it was the right thing to do.Mr Whitfield suggested constituents believe those who did what they said they would do, adding: ldquoI think the Government breaking the law and having to be told by the Supreme Court that they have broken the law severely undermines the trust in politicians.Next, with Russia raised as a potential threat, candidates were asked about defence spending.MacAskill thought the defence budget should not change, saying: ldquoThe dficulty that faces our military is that everything is being put into nuclear weapons and Trident. I do not believe in Trident, I do not believe in nuclear weapons.Mr Sisson questioned the British Armyrsquos future as ldquoBritish defence more and more seems to be integrated into European forces.Mr Hoy said the Conservatives would increase expenditure on defence by . per cent above the rate of inflation. He added: ldquoTrident makes us safer.Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThere is a commitment from a Labour government to maintain its position in NATO and the two per cent. There is a commitment to renew Trident.Mr OrsquoRiordan also said he would maintain the two per cent GDP target, adding: ldquoIrsquom not sure of the nature of the Russian threat ndash I think it is much more to do with cyberspace and the threat to our democracy.ldquoAs we know, Boris Johnson has a dossier on his desk which he hasnrsquot released that talks about Russian intervention in the European referendum and in the European elections.Question then focused on healing the isions from Brexit, Islamophobia, and anti-Semitism in politics.Mr Hoy said he thought ldquothe issue of accountability in politics is extremely important, adding that, on comments made by Boris Johnson mocking Muslim womenrsquos appearance, he thought ldquothe Prime Minister should be held to the same account for any particular phrases that he uses but ldquothat would be for him to comment on.Mr Whitfield said he believed the Labour Party should apologise to the Jewish community for its handling of complaints of anti-Semitism in the party.He added: ldquoWith regard to what happens to bring society together widely, I think a referendum or confirmatory vote would allow people to discuss and debate and then to express their feelings through ballot box.Mr MacAskill called for better education and more enforcement, adding: ldquoYou cannot just whip up hatred and say what you like.Lastly, the candidates were asked what three things they had done for East Lothian.Mr Hoy mentioned implementing the Change and Check breast cancer campaign, voting for East Lothian Councilrsquos emergency climate change declaration, and working with police to tackle anti-social behaviour and drug use in the county.Mr Whitfield highlighted helping people with Universal Credit payments, taking county art therapy charity The Teapot Trust to Westminster and, in his previous job as a primary school teacher, teaching children in East Lothian who he had now seen getting jobs and apprenticeships.Mr OrsquoRiordan listed his involvement in setting up the hustings and working with church groups, working towards achieving the Drem-Gullane path, and convening East Lothian Liberal Democrats.Mr MacAskill cited, in his time as Justice Secretary, establishing the CashBack for Communities scheme, helping implement minimum alcohol pricing, and reducing youth offending.Mr Sisson answered by describing his work as an electrician for the council, choosing to stand as an MP, and his involvement with Musselburgh Amateur Musical Association.When asked to sing the last line of his answer by the chair, the UKIP candidate obliged, belting out to the filled church that he hoped to deliver democratic freedom to constituents.

title: bid-build-new-hotel-replace-gullanes-mallard
story: Gullanersquos The Mallard Hotel has been run by the same family for more than half a century but new plans reveal a dramatic change for the East Links Road venue.Information boards were on display in the hotel last Thursday afternoon before a presentation was given to the villagersquos community council.Currently, the hotel is made up of  bedrooms, with a bar, bistro and garden room open to the public.However, the proposed new hotel ndash which would be built over three floors ndash would include  bedrooms, as well as a restaurant, lounge and spa facilities.Structured House Group is behind the plans, with a formal planning application expected to be with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department before the end of the year.Hotel owners Cameron and Susan Law intend to step down from the business, which has been in the family for  years,the proposals are given the green light.Susan, who is also chairman of Muirfield Riding Therapy, which offers free horse-riding for people with disabilities, stressed that The Mallard Hotel remained open for business as usual and would continue to be so for the foreseeable future.She told the Courier: ldquoI think, initially, I was quite shocked that it was going to be knocked down but in retrospect it is the best thing really.ldquoObviously, we will be sad to see it go but we will take The Mallard Hotel with us is how I am thinking now. It is very dear to us.About  people attended the public exhibition in the hotel and Tony Thomas, representing the developers, was pleased with how the six-hour drop-in event had gone.He said: ldquoIt was overwhelmingly positive ndash mainly because it is not housing [being proposed].ldquoThe vast majority of people really, really like the design. The only slight hiccup was two or three immediate neighbours were concerned over parking so we will look at that. If there is not enough parking, it spills out onto the street.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, was at the presentation and the meeting afterwards.He said there were concerns about the proposals and noted residentsrsquo worries about parking and traffic generated by the new hotel.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThe plans were well presented.ldquoWhat they are proposing is a fine installation and it looks as though it would be a good, upmarket, modern hotel with good facilities.ldquoThere is considerable concern in the community about the problems likely to arise from car parking.ldquoThat was the big issue in the discussions at the community council meeting.ldquoThere were a lot of people indicating signicant concern on that point. It is quite a heavily built-up residential area and already the parking is under pressure from residents.ldquoI would say the new hotel has signicantly more rooms than the present one. It is also supposedly going to have an upmarket restaurant, which will attract evening customers.

title: busy-a198-near-tranent-closed-several-evenings
story: There will be a full overnight closure of the A between the two roundabouts at the Bankton Junction. Drivers wanting to cross the bridge which travels over the A, linking Tranent to Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton, will face a y ersion.Joining and exiting the A at the junction will still be possible.From Monday until next Saturday , ldquoessential expansion joint replacement works will be carried out between the hours of pm and am each night.Closure of the bridge footpaths will also be required while the work is under way.Pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcycles under cc looking to cross the bridge will be marshalled safely across by the on-site team.A southbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A in an easterly direction towards Gladsmuir Junction.Traffic will be directed to take the exit at Gladsmuir Junction and, at the roundabout, will take the third exit onto the B.At the following roundabout, traffic will take the third exit to join the A but in a westerly direction towards Bankton Junction.From there, traffic will exit at Bankton Junction and take the second exit at the roundabout to rejoin the A.Meanwhile, A northbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A westbound.Traffic will proceed towards Dolphingstone and will exit at the next junction.From there, traffic will then take a right turn onto the A, crossing the A and will take a further right turn to rejoin the eastbound carriageway of the A.Traffic will follow this route to take the exit at Bankton Junction and at the roundabout will take the first exit to rejoin the A.All works are weather dependent and may be cancelled or rescheduledweather conditions are not favourable.This scheme has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, the emergency services and East Lothian Council.

title: rugby-players-tackle-giant-jenners-xmas-tree
story: This yearrsquos tree is a ft-high Norway spruce that was grown in Stirling. It was supplied by Conox, which has provided Christmas trees for Edinburghrsquos Christmas market and Leicester Square in London.Ross High RFC has helped get the tree in place in Jenners for the past  years, a tradition which started after one former member had a connection to the company K which helps hoist the tree and put on the lights.John Tinlin, Ross High Rugby Club president, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos tree was not as big as it usually is but the guys all know the script.ldquoWe have to take the tree in through the revolving doors at the front of the store since there is no other way to bring it in, so we need to be very careful.ldquoThe doors are actually taken off so there is enough room. It was a tight squeeze but we managed.ldquoIt was well wrapped, which made it a lot easier.Ross High sent a team of  along to help bring the tree into the iconic Princes Street store, with the whole process taking just  minutes.John added: ldquoIt was quicker than usual.The team volunteer their time but are rewarded with pizza by the staff at Jenners.The process is a very Scottish affair, with rugby club members wearing kilts and music performed on bagpipes.Once the tree is brought in, staff from K abseil from the roof, helping to hoist it up and put the lights on ndash a process which takes place overnight.The lights were turned on by five-year-old Chloe from Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital, who won the opportunity through a charity auction.Following reports that Jenners might leave Princes Street and moving to another city centre location, John added: ldquoHopefully the tradition goes ahead again next year as we have been a part of it for such a long time.

title: grandfathers-five-decade-link-christian-aid-recognised
story: John Woodrsquos links to Christian Aid date back more than half a century and he has now been presented with a certicate to mark his commitment to the good cause.The -year-old, of Haddingtonrsquos Herdmanflatt, was taken by surprise at a recent quiz night in St Maryrsquos Parish Church for the charity, which works to support sustainable development, stop poverty and provide disaster relief.He said: ldquoI suppose after receiving the certicate I felt quite humbled about it really.ldquoIt was a surprise and I was pleased afterwards.The certicate reads: ldquoChristian Aid presents this award to John Wood in recognition of his  plus years of outstanding commitment in transforming the lives of the poor, marginalised and vulnerable.Mr Wood first got involved with the charity in the early s when he was instrumental in setting up the Haddington branch of the organisation.It has grown considerably since then, raising thousands of pounds for the international charity each year.The grandfather-of-four said: ldquoA chap from Edinburgh came out, Jimmy Hodge, who was the sole organiser of Christian Aid in Scotland at that time, and spoke about Christian Aid in the West Church.ldquoThat was the start of Christian Aid in Haddington.ldquoThe first big event was a sponsored -mile walk.ldquoAll the churches in Haddington were involved and walked to North Berwick, along the coast and back to Haddington.Since then, ious events have been organised for the charity, with the annual focus on Christian Aid Week.Members from Holy Trinity Church, St Maryrsquos Parish Church and West Church join forces for the house-to-house collection, which takes place each May.Mr Wood, who stepped down from the townrsquos Christian Aid committee earlier this year, remains involved with Holy Trinity Church, where he has been a minister for a number of years.Graham Coe, who is a member of the townrsquos Christian Aid committee, handed over the certicate to Mr Wood, who also worked with the Courier for almost  years firstly, as a compositor and then as a proof reader.Janet Chrystal, Christian Aid organiser for Haddington, said: ldquoJohn has been a mainstay in Haddington for a number of years.ldquoThe churches in Haddington have worked together for Christian Aid and we have had a joint committee and John represented Holy Trinity Church.ldquoHe stepped back at the end of August and his place has been taken by two people, which tells you his level of commitment.ldquoHe did not know he was getting the presentation, it was a surprise, but, of course, he was there as he always supports Christian Aid events.

title: santas-helping-send-north-berwick-teenager-ghana
story: Beth Poole, , who lives on Wamphray Road, left North Berwick High School in the summer.Before attending the University of Glasgow to study neuroscience, she is taking a year out to teach English and maths at a junior school in the Volta region of the West African country.She leaves next month and will be in Africa for eight months, living with a host family based within the community while she is out there.And to help fund her trip, she is organising this yearrsquos North Berwick Santa Run, which takes place next Sunday .Her African adventure is organised through Project Trust.Beth told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom really excited and nervous ndash it will be nerve-wracking at first. I am hoping it will be very rewarding. Irsquom excited to see all of the new cultures as well ndash Irsquom hoping to take some sports gear with me, Irsquove been asking some friends for their old hockey sticks.ldquoIrsquom going to teach my own class when Irsquom out there so Irsquom going on a one-week teaching course before I go.In order to go to Ghana, Beth needs to raise pound, and currently has pound, left, so has decided to host this yearrsquos Santa Run.Registration opens at .am on the day, with runs beginning at am outside the Hope Rooms ndash k, k and k runs are on offer.The route takes runners across ious parts of North Berwick, with the k heading out to Broad Sands.The routes involve water and climbing over rocky sections, so appropriate shoes and winter clothing are advised.There are some age restrictions on the runs: the k is open for all ages, with children under seven to be accompanied by an adult the k is open to those  years and over and the k for those aged  and over.Entry for under-sevens is pound, under-s pay pound and adults pound, with Scottish Athletics members receiving a pound discount.All of the money raised at the Santa Run goes towards Bethrsquos fundraising efforts.She added: ldquoItrsquos been a lot more dficult to organise than I thought but hopefully Irsquove done enough. I know itrsquos quite tough to run on the beach, but we will all be fine.Enter the run at entrycentral festival  or email bethpoole@gmailSince the run is Santa Christmas themed, participants are encouraged to wear Christmas clothing.Dogs are welcomewell behaved and on a lead.Those not taking part are welcome to spectate and support, with tea, coffee and cakes for sale in the Hope Rooms.Beach Wheelchairs, where Bethrsquos mum Cath is a volunteer, is also open and available for hire to allow everyone to take part in the event.Participants receive a Santa hat on arrival and a hot drink and home baking after completing their run.

title: tims-tales-anne-franks-legacy
story: WHILE watching a film adaptation of John Greenrsquos wonderful book The Fault In Our Stars last night, there was a scene in which the main character, a young woman suffering from cancer, climbs the stairs into the attic used by Anne Frank.My six-year-old Skye was watching with me and she was having her last five minutes before bedtime. But she asked why the young woman was so determined to climb the stairs, even though she was clearly very ill and finding it dficult.This led to me mentioning who Anne Frank was and that people visit the attic because itrsquos the place where she hid.ldquoWhy was she hiding  was the inevitable question, just as bedtime arrived.I was suddenly presented with a dilemma, not so much that bedtime was now delayed, but how to explain to a six-year-old the depth of evil and hatred that was the reason for Anne Frank having to hide in an attic with her family. And then whether to explain what happened to her after she was discovered.I knew that I couldnrsquot just ignore her question. So we searched for images of Anne Frank, which meant she became a real person for my daughter.Skye studied her and said she looked nice and kind, and asked again why she was hiding.I explained that people who didnrsquot even know her hated her just because she was a bit dferent to them. I couldnrsquot explain the horrors of genocide and concentration camps, but she understood that Anne Frank and her family must have been really scared to hide in an attic.ldquoWhat happened to her  asked Skye as she dressed for bed.This was not a bedtime story I wanted to tell. Indeed, for a child so young, it was not a story I wanted to tell at all. She knows there are bad people and staying safe is important, but we feel the need to protect our children from the evil and hatred that is sadly so deep-seated.But it is at this young age that the seeds of intolerance and hatred can be plantedthey are not encouraged and helped to feel empathy to others, including those who are dferent in fact, especially those who are dferent.So I told her a lsquochild-friendlyrsquo version of Anne Frankrsquos story,there can be such a thing. I gave no details of the horror of the Holocaust but we imagined how she must have missed her family when they were split up, and how sad it was that she died not long before the war ended.She wanted to look at Anne Frankrsquos photo again and say goodnight to her.ldquoThank goodness that could never happen to us here, could it dad ldquoNo, that is not going to happen, and we have to make sure it doesnrsquot happen to anyone  either, I reassured her.I felt quite emotional as I went downstairs with my kids sleeping safely in their cosy beds. I thought of the families in Syria who cannot keep their children safe from hatred and violence. I knew that such horrors could happen anywhere, at any time yes, even here yes, maybe even to us or our neighbours or friends. In fact, hatred of dference is indeed amongst us.A friend of mine was on a bus heading from East Lothian into Edinburgh last week and witnessed a horrible racist verbal assault on a Polish family. The horric murders in London are also part of the same hatred of dference ndash a man so full of hatred for people who think dferently that he randomly killed two amazing young people.Hatred is a virus that can infect any society and any inidual in it. History has taught us that fanning its flames can be an easy way for politicians to win power. But like real fire, once itrsquos released it can spread and destroy uncontrollably.People say fight fire with fire, but here the comparison ends, for we cannot fight hatred with hatred. Hatred only spawns more of it.And so I searched for words of that remarkable young woman Anne Frank, who left her diary behind, unknowing that it would be her gt to the world. Words I could share with my daughter, from one young thinking child to another. Despite writing at a time of unimaginable fear and horror, in her diary she has left us a timeless message of hope that comes from her rejection of hate:ldquoItrsquos dficult in times like these ideals, dreams and cherished hopes rise within us, only to be crushed by grim reality. Itrsquos a wonder I havenrsquot abandoned all my ideals, they seem so absurd and impractical. Yet I cling to them because I still believe, in spite of everything, that people are truly good at heart.It is our responsibility to live up to that inspiring message from a young woman who was a victim of the hate she rejected utterly to show our children, our family and friends, our colleagues and those we meet on a bus, that love, tolerance, empathy and respect of dference is the counter to hate.And we should expect no less from all our politicians.

title: bid-replace-old-boxing-gym-housing
story: REM Associates have lodged planning applications seeking to replace the th century former Tranent Methodist Church building on Bridge Street with four two-bedroom flats.They submitted the applications on behalf of businessman and premises owner Alex Brown, who founded Bronx Boxing Gym, which was based at the old church, a decade ago.In recent years, Mr Brown had no involvement in the running of the boxing club but still let its boxers use the building.However, costly repairs were needed to make the former church safe, which led to the boxing club vacating the premises.Earlier this year, the club moved to the newly established Fit-in Fitness Gym on High Street, Musselburgh.A planning application has been submitted for the former church building and the east wall which faces the car park on Coal Neuk to be demolished.Drawings included within a second planning application show designs for erecting four two-bedroom flats with a basement car park with space for four cars.

title: familys-spectacular-christmas-lights-display
story: The Woods family open their very own Santarsquos grotto and decorate their home each year to raise money for Mission Christmas and Cash for Kids.This year, there are more than , lights at their family home and in their garden.Dad Stevie Woods said the family ldquojust love Christmas and hope the stream of visitors theyrsquore expecting will leave donations for charity, either cash or a toy.They raised pound on their opening night.The lights were switched on for visitors on Sunday at pm and will be on from .pm to pm daily until Christmas.The grotto is open for visitors, who can enjoy the Disney characters painted on the inside and the Christmas films playing.There is also a Santa Sleigh where children can get their photograph taken, and this year there will be the addition of a Santa train, which Stevie made himself out of whisky barrels.He said: ldquoLast year we raised about pound so wersquore hoping to beat that. There are more lights up and wersquore running a raffle competition.ldquoIt makes it worthwhile to beat the total every year.ldquoWe have been handed in toys and prizes already.ldquoPeople are able to make donations and leave gts which will be sent away to charity. We do this because we just love Christmas ndash we have our tree up already.ldquoWe have a nine-year-old daughter, Ellie, and we started this with her and it has just got bigger and bigger every year.ldquoMy we Sheena designs the grotto and I do the lights and the garden.

title: general-election-2019-voting-system-works
story: Unlike the single transferable vote system used in the East Lothian Council elections, FPTP is a straight race to the line, with voters only allowed to vote for one candidate and the candidate with the most votes winning.Voters mark an x on their ballot paper next to the candidate they wish to vote for - they must not mark any of the other candidates boxes or their ballot paper will be spoilt.Once all the votes across the constituency have been tallied, the candidate with the most votes is elected.Voting takes place between am and pm on Thursday, December , with the East Lothian result expected to be declared some time early in the morning, potentially any time between about am and about am, although this is liable to change depending on how close the result is.The final UK-wide result is not expected to be known until well into the Friday morning.The General Election is to elect the UK Government at Westminster, with all  seats across Scotland, England, Wales and Northern Ireland up for grabs.To win a majority, a party would need at least  seats.Traditionally, a General Election is held only once every five years, but this will be the third General Election since May , coming only two and a half years after the last one in June .The last election resulted in a hung parliament, with the Conservatives losing their majority and finishing with  seats, while Labour came second with seats.In Scotland, the SNP won  of the  seats, more than half, although that did represent a loss of  seats from their historic  result. However, it was still enough to see them finish as the third largest party across the UK, well ahead of the fourth-placed Liberal Democrats, who won  seats UK-wide.The Conservatives increased their number of seats in Scotland from one to  to finish second, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats, both of whom also had won only one seat in Scotland in , also made gains, winning seven and four seats respectively.East Lothian, which had been one of a swathe of Labour seats to fall to the SNP in , was one of Labours gains last time around in , Martin Whitfield overturning sitting MP George Kerevans majority of nearly , to regain the seat for Labour with a majority of ,.The Conservatives Sheila Low was a close third, a little over  votes behind the SNP.Unlike in the council elections and the Scottish Parliament elections,  and -year-olds cannot vote in the General Election - voters must be  or over.

title: general-election-2019-statement-east-lothian-constituency-conservative-candidate-craig-hoy
story: East Lothian is the second fastest growing area in Scotland. The speed of development is challenging our schools, our hospitals and GPs surgeries, our roads and our railways. And itrsquos challenging our local environment: the very thing that attracts so many people to live here.So,elected as your MP, I will put East Lothianrsquos infrastructure first ndash and stand firm against any attempt by the SNP to force thousands more homes on East Lothian. This will be my number one priority.Climate change affects us all but it will hit younger residents hardest. As a member of East Lothian Council, I backed the climate change emergency declaration. But itrsquos vital we match words with deeds. As your MP, I will do that. I am committed to promoting a secure and low-carbon-based economy, supporting sustainable local transport and resources across East Lothian.I also want to tackle the scourge of poverty in East Lothian. The best way of lting people out of poverty is to create new, skilled jobs and apprenticeships. Thatrsquos why I will push for more investment to create jobs at the former Cockenzie Power Station site and the new Innovation Park at Queen Margaret University.As your MP, I will work hard for those who work hard. But I will work twice as hard for the poorest and most vulnerable members of our community. I will always stand up for older people and will push for the BBC to reverse its decision to remove free TV licences from the over-s.But we cannot escape one simple fact. The SNP donrsquot see this election as being about East Lothianrsquos future but instead as an opportunity to mount lsquoone final heaversquo for independence. And Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour Party is ready to help them do it.The SNP wants next year to be the year of two isive referendums. We need to send a clear message to Nicola Sturgeon: we donrsquot want another independence referendum.The only way to do that is to vote Scottish Conservative, because Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour Party is simply too weak and ided to win here.My position is unambiguous: no s, no buts, no IndyRef.Put simply, I want to go to Westminster to be East Lothianrsquos voice in Parliament, not remove your voice from it.
